: CRUDE OIL OBTAINED FROM IRAN : PAYMENTS 0553/08 01.
? () ? () , ? asked the Minister of Petroleum and Petroleum Resources Development,:
(i) the quantity of crude oil imported from Iran for the last 15 years to-date;

(ii) the price we have bought from Iran along with the world market price as of that date; (iii) whether we have paid for the purchase or bought on credit; and (iv) if on credit the period and the interest rates? (b) Will he state the total outstanding payments up to-date for Petroleum purchase from Iran?

asked the Minister of Highways and Road Development , : (a) Will he inform this House the amount of money been allocated and really spent for development and maintenance of roads, for the last 05 years per year basis? (b) Will he state, (i) the 10 important roads that have been maintained and the amount of money spent, separately; (ii) the names of the new highways and expressways that are going to be constructed; (iii) the estimated cost along with the date that construction starts and the date expected to be completed; (iv) names of the tenderers and their bid prices; and (v) the funding source and the total cost with interest rate for the loan? (c) If not, why?

REGIONAL GAM UDAWA PROGRAME : HOUSING LOANS 1114/08 7.

asked the Minister of Housing and Common Amenities,: (a) Is she aware that, (i) loans with the value of Rs. 12,500/- each at the time of granting them were given to build houses in the lands situated at the Diddiliya division, 73A, Ambalangoda which were given under the Regional Gam Udawa programme in the year 1992; and (ii) these housing loans were written off as overdue housing loans at a later stage? (b) Will she state,

(i) the reason for subjecting the persons who have not paid these housing loans to a ban on access to their houses and property on orders given by a court of law; and (ii) whether any relief will be provided to these innocent people by writing off these housing loans as overdue housing loans? (c) If not, why?
( () - , ) (The Hon. (Mrs.) Ferial Ismail Ashraff - Minister of Housing and Commom Amenities) () (i) . (ii) . . () (i) . (ii) . () .

asked the Minister of Plantation Industries,(1) (a) Is he aware that, (i) a person by the name of P.N. Wilson residing at No.29, Isadeen Colony, Dekinda, Nawalapitiya, served as an Assistant Field Officer in Catabula Barkale estate that belongs to Kahawatta Plantation Company; and (ii) he has been interdicted with effect from 02.04.1998? (b) Will he inform this House, (i) the decision given at the inquiry conducted on 25.06.1999 following a complaint made by Mr. Wilson to the Senior Labour Officer in Nawalapitiya; (ii) the reason for the dismissal of the complaint without conducting proper investigations regarding the repeated complaints made with regard to the aforesaid matter; and (iii) whether Mr. Wilson who was subjected to a severe injustice will be reinstated with his arrears of salary? (c) If not, why?

() , ? asked the Minister of Indigenous Medicine,: (a) Will he inform this House, (i) the names and the qualifications of the persons who hold the posts of the Secretary to the Ministry of Indigenous Medicine, the Commissioner of Ayurveda and the Deputy Commissioner of Ayurveda; (ii) if they have obtained special qualifications with relevance to their respective posts what those qualifications are; (iii) whether they have an understanding of the Ayurvedic System of Medicine or the administrative requirements of the system; and (iv) if they do not possess such an understanding, the reason for appointing them to the aforesaid posts? (b) Will he admit that there are persons who possess higher educational qualifications when compared to the aforesaid officials and have obtained postgraduate degrees (with relevance to the subject and the administration) in the Ayurvedic Service? : : CONSERVATION OF PLACES OF ARCHAEOLOGICAL VALUE : MONEY ALLOCATED

() , ? asked the Minister of Cultural Affairs and National Heritage: (a) Will he inform this House, (i) the amount of money allocated for the conservation of the places with an archaeological value in the year 2008; (ii) the amount of money spent for the above mentioned purpose up to now; and (iii) the names of the places for which the aforesaid amount of money was spent? (b) Will he submit to this House, (i) whether the Department of Archaeology has a plan for the conservation of the aforesaid places; and (ii) the names of the places that should be given priority according to the order in which they have been placed on the plan mentioned above? (c) If not, why?

() , ? asked the Minister of Agricultural Development and Agrarian Services,: (a) Is he aware that the bund of the Nabiriththankadawara tank , which comes under the Pannala Divisional Secretariat Division in the Kurunegala District, has breached on 12.11.2005?

(b) Will he inform this House, (i) the number of farmer families that have been displaced as a result of the breach of the tank bund; (ii) whether the paddy field which comes under the aforesaid tank can be used for cultivation purposes; and (iii) whether measures have been taken to provide relief to the farming community which has been displaced? asked the Minister of Housing and Common Amenities,: (a) Will she inform this House, (i) whether there had been a circuit bungalow belonging to National Housing Development Authority on the 7th floor of the Liberty Plaza building in Colpetty; and (ii) of the name of the company to which the aforesaid circuit bungalow was sold and the amount of money for which it was sold? (b) Will she inform this House, (i) whether a valuation was obtained from the Government Valuer with relevance to the aforesaid sale; (ii) if not, the person from whom the valuation for the sale was obtained; and (iii) whether such a valuation is legal? (c) Will she state whether legal action will be taken with regard to the aforesaid transaction? (d) If not, why?

asked the Minister of Housing and Common Amenities: (a) Will she submit to this House, (i) whether a land belonging to the National Housing Development Authority was situated on the Kirimandala Mawatha; (ii) the extent of that land; (iii) the name of the institution to which the relevant land was sold and the amount of money for which it was sold; and (iv) whether a valuation was obtained from the Government Valuers for the above mentioned sale? (b) Will she state, (i) whether a Cabinet approval has been obtained for the sale of the aforesaid land; and (ii) whether steps will be taken against the relevant authorities if this land has been sold without obtaining Cabinet approval and the relevant valuation done by the Government? (c) If not, why?

() , ? asked the Minister of Trade, Marketing Development, Co-operatives and Consumer Services: (a) Will he inform this House, (i) whether the Building Material Corporation entered into an agreement for the supply of building materials, with a non-governmental organization named, Lawrence Friendship Organization in 2005; (ii) whether the building materials have been supplied to the relevant non governmental organization, in keeping with the above mentioned agreement; and (iii) if the aforesaid corporation was not able to supply materials as agreed, the course of action that was followed with regard to it? (b) Will he submit to this House, (i) the amount of money that had to be paid back to the non-governmental organization due to the failure to fulfill the conditions of the aforesaid agreement; and (ii) the location of the land that was sold to find money for it? (c) Will he state, the steps that have been taken against the officers who are responsible for causing such financial losses? (d) If not, why?

: : VOTE OF CONDOLENCE : HON. ANURA BANDARANAIKE [. . 10.35] ( ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Nimal Siripala de Silva - Minister of Healthcare and Nutrition and Leader of the House of Parliament) , 1970 - , , , , 2008 16 . . . 1949 15 . . . . . . . . "" . . . , 1971
( - ) (The Hon. Ranil Wickremasinghe - Leader of the Opposition)

Hon. Speaker, this House is poorer by the loss of Anura Bandaranaike. A Parliament defines its character through the composition of the Members of the House. From time to time, from election to election, this composition changes naturally. It must reflect the socio-

economic composition of any country. But, throughout this period there are Members who serve for a long time and who make an ongoing contribution to the work of the House, to the proceedings of the House and thereby help to uplift the House in the eyes of the citizens of the country.

Now, Anura Bandaranaike falls into that category and going by that yardstick, we can always say that his demise is a loss to the Parliamentary System of Sri Lanka and also to those who believe in the Commonwealth Parliamentary System throughout the world. Anura Bandaranaike served this House as a Member, as a Leader of the Opposition, as a Minister and as a Speaker. But, he will be best remembered for his contributions as a Member of the Opposition, as the Leader of the Opposition and as the Speaker.

When he entered Parliament in 1977, it was a depleted Sri Lanka Freedom Party and the role that Anura Bandaranaike played at that time is known to a few of us who were in this House, because he took the lead in holding up the flag of the Parliamentary Opposition, not only as a Member but also when he became the Leader of the Opposition, he occupied this post which got further depleted by the absence of the TULF. Those were difficult days. But, as the system of Executive President was introduced into this country in 1978, Anura had certainly made a great contribution in defining and upholding the role of the Opposition under the 1978 Constitution. If the Opposition was silent at that time, there would be no place for it. A few of them were able to ensure that the Government was made answerable, the Government was kept on its toes and the dissenting voices in the country were reflected in this House. Those were difficult days. Sometimes Anura Bandaranaike had to speak on behalf of the Members of the TULF, with whose policies he did not agree but nevertheless, some of their rights had to be safeguarded. At difficult times, he had to agree with the Government, despite the fact that the majority in this party wanted to disagree. Those are traits of leadership and he displayed that again when he became the Speaker; when he had to uphold the rights of Parliament, the sovereignty of Parliament and the power of Parliament against courts and all other authorities which sought to challenge these. The ruling he has given in this House is a historic one and will be an illustrious part of our record. Certainly Anuras contribution as various ministers should not be belittled in that way. But the fact is that he, having been a Member of the Opposition, the Leader of the Opposition and the Speaker, made a greater contribution, and I am sure he will be remembered for that role because Anura was essentially a Parliamentarian. From the very beginning, from the time I remembered him, before he came to this House, he liked to make speeches and from here, he made those speeches. Having inherited the Parliamentary traditions from his father,

knowing how the Legislative Council operated when his ancestors were Members of it, he brought into the House a tradition which most of us did not have, and he continued to uphold those traditions and those principles despite changing times and changing circumstances. That contribution is what I thought I should specifically mention here in this House. I do not want to go into length about Anura and his family. We knew each other. We knew the families well but we happened to be on opposite sides.

I never thought that I would enter Parliament. I never had any idea and I always thought that Anura would enter Parliament and sit on the Government Benches. But, it happened that we both entered together and I sat on the Government Benches while he sat in the Opposition. I never thought that we would have the occasion of sitting together on the same side. We did so. Firstly, in Government, then in the Opposition and in the last part of his career, the last few days, in the Opposition. Anura was a person who had many ambitions. Unfortunately, he could not achieve all of them. He had ambitions of his Party and of Government. But, he bore those disappointments well. He talked about it occasionally but nevertheless realized that he had a role to play in politics. He continued to play the role in Government as a Minister, in the Opposition as a Member who was always forthright in his views and always got up when he found the rights of the opposition or the rights of citizens were being transgressed.

Anura was a person who enjoyed life. As he enjoyed life, he would not allow his disappointments to stand in the way. He was well-read. He enjoyed films. He had one of the largest collections of videos and DVDs of movies in Sri Lanka. He liked to travel and he liked to give us the benefit of his knowledge. He was a very easy-going person and sometimes you feel that he indulged too much and the indulgence itself took a toll on his health. Anura was a person who did not believe in limitations. He thought life was too good; that we should not in any way try to impose limitations in the way we enjoyed. So, he went around the world. He went around the country. He spoke well. He relaxed well and I must say that as far as Anura was concerned, he did not have vengeance in his heart; he did not. He may criticize you; he may even abuse you; he may shout at you but it was all forgotten after the speech. It is very rare to meet a person like that and rarer still to meet a person who, when he ended politics, was poorer than when he started. Anura and I used to speak about politics today, the standards that were not being kept; the standards that were not being maintained and how the public were looking down on Parliament and on Members of Parliament and he said, I am proud that I have not made a cent and I am poorer today than when I entered Parliament". I know that. He would tell me of some of the measures he had taken. But, I suppose Anura in his own way had nothing to worry.

I think I had the opportunity of having not only the late Hon. Anura Bandaranaike, but also another Colleague, the Chief Government Whip, the Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena, in Parliament. Anura was a person who was very outgoing. There were times when he was depressed. You could notice it, but most of the time, he was outgoing. He knew many world personalities. But, towards the end of his life, he was shattered by the assassination of Benazir Bhutto. He liked Benazir Bhutto. She came here when he launched his book and when he heard that she was assassinated, he was really shaken. Anuras last illness, he concealed from all of us. He would not tell anyone that he was ill. I got to know about it by chance. I was due to meet him in January after returning from India and when I got back, I found that he had gone to Singapore. The last few weeks I had the occasion to visit him regularly both at Ackland House and the hospital, and though the end was near he never showed it. When I used to go and meet him, we used to talk about politics, about international affairs; we talked a lot about the democratic primary, whether Hillary Clinton or Barack Obama will be the democratic nominee, because week by week the results of the primaries were coming and also about the political situation in Sri Lanka. We used to talk about all that. Very rarely did we ever touch on his health and at the end of it I used to say, "Well , Anura, we will meet again; I will drop in to see you". Then, one morning when I was at home, I got the message that Anura Bandaranaike had passed away. So, I have lost a Friend, I have lost a Colleague and the House has lost a Member who could have made a valuable contribution in time to come. I do not want to speak at length - Anura was a person who spoke using a lot of quotations - but to speak from the heart is the best and I want to wish my friend. May he attain Nibbana. [. . 11.07] (, , , )
( - , , ) (The Hon. Ratnasiri Wickramanayaka - Prime Minister, Minister of Internal Administration and Deputy Minister of Defence, Public Security, Law and Order) , , . , . . . . , . ? ; .

, , . Whereupon MR. SPEAKER left the Chair, and THE HON. LALITH DISSANAYAKE took the Chair. . ( . ) (The Hon. N. Sri Kantha) , . , 1959 25 .... , , , 26 , , . , , , - , , . . . , . - , .
1977 - , , . - - . , 1977 . , , . . . . 2007 23 , Code of Criminal Procedure (Special Provisions) Bill ( ) . . , . . , , . , . . . , . 1983 .. ,
( - , ) (The Hon. Dew Gunasekara -Minister of Constitutional Affairs and National Integration)
Mr. Presiding Member, I wish to make some preliminary observations relating to the Votes of

Condolence in general, before I come to the subject proper. We are moving this Vote of Condolence on a distinguished Speaker of this House after a lapse of almost one year. I have raised this matter earlier and I do repeat it now. The names of so many other Members who are dead and gone are already lined up for similar Votes of Condolence. Mr. Presiding Member, can we be so disrespectful as that? Self-critically, we must admit that such an undue delay is not at all in keeping with the best traditions of this House. The state of affairs of this House has deteriorated so far to be disrespectful even to the dead - to many a distinguished Member of this House, some who had made a significant contribution to the economy of our country and for the cause of our people. Mr. Presiding Member, I wish to bring to your recollection that when the Hon. D.M. Rajapaksa, Member of the State Council for Hambantota, the Lion of Ruhuna, collapsed in this House and died, the then Hon. Leader of the House, the Hon. D.S. Senanayake, within a few hours of his death moved the suspension of other work of the House and proposed the Vote of Condolence on that great man. That should be the spirit of this House and that has been the well-established tradition since the State Council days. But, that has been completely ignored and we had to wait 365 days to pay our tribute to the distinguished former Speaker, the Hon. Anura Bandaranaike. Mr. Presiding Member, I am not finding fault with the Hon. Speaker. I raised this matter over and over again at the Party Leaders Meetings and my Friend, the Hon. Chief Government Whip, also, I think repeatedly raised this question at the Party Leaders Meetings and at various other places. The Hon. Anura Bandaranaike was a Speaker of this House, even the Leader of the Opposition of this House, a Cabinet Minister in several administrations, one of the finest debaters that this country has produced and it took us one long year to move this Vote of Condolence. It was so in respect of the other Members also. That is by the way. But, I could not allow this lapse on our part to go unchallenged. Let us be more cultured and not be disrespectful at least to the dead. Mr. Presiding Member, I recall my first meeting with the Hon. Anura Bandaranaike at Temple Trees, soon after his return to the Island after his higher education. At that stage, he was associated with the Sri Lanka Freedom Party's Youth Organization. I can remember that I invited him to deliver a talk on Lenin in English and that meeting was presided over by Mr. George Rajapaksa, the father of the Hon. (Mrs.) Nirupama Rajapaksa. That, I think was his maiden delivery in English after his return from London and it was a stunning speech, not only from the point of view of his style of delivery, but also from his knowledge of history and his critical analysis of Lenin.

In the 1980s, I had the privilege of associating myself with the Hon. Anura Bandaranaike very closely and serve with him as a Member of the Opposition in this House, under his leadership as the Leader of the Opposition. He held the Floor ferociously along with eight of us in the Opposition against 215 Members on the Government side. He also had a very tough time in dealing with the Speakers of those days and confronting a galaxy of intellectual giants in the Front Benches of the Government, including at that stage, the most unruly Member, Mr. Ranil Wickremasinghe, although he is today a tamed Leader of the Opposition. He was a good Leader of the Opposition. Therefore, although we were diametrically opposed politically and ideologically, as a novice in this House I was given the privilege of winding up two Debates on the Budgets presented by the Hon. Ronnie de Mel. I also had the privilege to join him in the delegation to the General Assembly of the United Nations when he was the Foreign Minister. He was friendly; he was cheerful; he was cultured; honourable; humane and above all, a man of the highest integrity. I shall ever remember his landmark and historic ruling given by him as Speaker on the Floor of this House on a Supreme Court Decision. When the judiciary was attempting to encroach on the frontiers of the legislature, he defended valiantly on the Floor of the House; he defended the legislature and that is where he made his mark as the Speaker. I associate myself with the sentiments expressed by all the previous speakers on both sides of the House. To save time, I do not want to repeat or reiterate them. Mr. Presiding Member, I believe, when discussing a Vote of Condolence of this nature on a distinguished Member of this House, as the Hon. Anura Bandaranaike, we should not restrict ourselves to mere eulogies, appreciations, evaluations or admirations. After all, he was the son of two Prime Ministers with an outstanding, illustrious and a distinguished social-political background. He served as a Member in different capacities for over 35 years on both sides of the House and also as the Speaker. We all know that he could not achieve what he aspired for. It is necessary as students of history, as students of political science to inquire and investigate as to why he failed, where he failed and how he failed. What are the objective and subjective factors which contributed to his failure to achieve what he aspired for? It is necessary to gain an insight into his political life, contemporary political trends and developments and prevalent political culture if we are to make an assessment and evaluation and draw necessary conclusions. Mr. Presiding Member, it is my sense of history and political judgment that he failed because he placed himself as a "right of centre" of politics in a party like the

Sri Lanka Freedom Party. Maybe he stood by his own political convictions. But, this was the fundamental failure. When he was ready, luck did not come and when luck dawned on him he was not ready. So no one can be blamed, except himself. Mr. Presiding Member, as a politician of a right of centre in the SLFP, I think all such leaders receded into the political oblivion. In those days, even those who were pushed into power or forced into power by the force of events like the late Hon. W. Dahanayaka and the late Hon. C.P.D. Silva, met with the same fate. Secondly, he was probably influenced by the neo-conservative political thinkers. Thirdly, even as a right of centre he was probably more dogmatic and less pragmatic. Fourthly, he was prone to subjectivism and unconcerned with the objective realities that subjectivism overpowered him. Fifthly, his pride, with due respect to him, was his guiding principle. Sixthly, he relied upon the superstructure of the party and not so much of the infrastructure of the party. Seventhly, he failed because he was surrounded by a circle of friends, some of whom were social climbers, careerists, opportunists who fattened themselves and who made their fortunes and probably they would have contributed to paralyze his political fortunes. Mr. Presiding Member, in the last days I can remember he confessed certain things to me personally as to why he failed politically. I do not propose to come out with those and I will find some other time later to make things known to the people. As a Friend and as a Colleague, I pay my tribute to the Hon. Anura Bandaranaike for all what he has done for the cause of the people, for the cause of the country and I wish, Mr. Presiding Member, through you, to convey our deepest sympathies to Sunethra and Chandrika, his two sisters. Thank you. [. . 12.12] ( ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena-Minister of Urban Development and Sacred Area Development and Chief Government Whip) , . , . . 1977 .

, , [ ] . Whereupon THE HON. LALITH DISSANAYAKE left the Chair, and MR. DEPUTY CHAIRMAN OF COMMITTEES [THE HON. RAMALINGAM CHANDRASEKAR] took the Chair. ( ) (The Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena) . . .. . . . . 2004 . 1956 . 2004 , , . .

, . 2004 . , , , , . , , . , . . . . . , , , . . , 1955 . , . . , , . . He was a Man with an unblemished character Devoted dedication, unsurpassed sacrifice, unrivalled honesty, Incorruptibility and foresight, Admired by his opponents,............... honoured by rivals, Be loved by his people. A Man keen in thought, bold in gesture Tough from out but mild from within. A Man who preached what he practised - Fearing none or nothing, bearing in mind only the well-being of his Motherland

A Man who closed the dogmatic ways, And proposed the path of realities to the situation A Man who contributed in a very large measure in defence of his Motherland, The melodious echoes of which will be heard for generations to come. A Man called "Anura Priyadarshi Dias Bandaranaike". Thank you. [. . 12.35] . . ( ) ( . . - ) (The Hon. (Prof.) W.A. Wiswa Warnapala- Minister of Higher Education) Mr. Deputy Chairman of Committees, it is with a deep sense of grief that I stand up in this House to pay tribute to one of the leading sons of Sri Lanka. The late Mr. Anura Bandaranaike was a special kind of politician who adorned this House for more than three decades. He entered Parliament as a very young man and he represented the multi-member constituency of Nuwara Eliya-Maskeliya. He held a number of important portfolios in this House. He became the youngest Leader of the Opposition and another position to which he was elected was the Speakership in this House. As the Speaker, he took certain decisions to protect the integrity of this House. He was a strong advocate of the supremacy of Parliament. He believed in the doctrine of Parliamentary sovereignty. The late Mr. Anura Bandaranaike, as the Speaker of this august Assembly did not allow the Judiciary to make inroads into the established doctrine of Parliamentary sovereignty. In that sense, the late Mr. Anura Bandaranaike was a Parliamentarian par excellence. He was an excellent speaker. Every speech of his was full of facts and he always beautified it with a good quotation from a leading author. He did a thorough study of the subject or the issue before he decided to speak on it in this House. He was well-read. I know that he was a lover of books. He had a good collection of books. He was an avid reader and specialized in Western History and Politics. He used to tell us that it is through the study of biographies that a history of a period could be well understood. Therefore, he was reading all biographies of all leading politicians throughout the world. As a Member of Parliament, he made use of all the parliamentary instruments in this House to make Parliamentary Government an effective and efficient form of government. He held a number of important portfolios. He was at one time the Minister of Higher Education which I occupy today and he held the portfolios of the Minister of

Industry and Investment Promotion and Minister of Tourism, Minister of Foreign Affairs and Minister of National Heritage. In the sphere of Foreign Affairs, he was a peer who knew the subject. He knew the subject thoroughly. He wanted to specialize in foreign policy matters. He spoke on foreign policy more in the nature of an expert on the subject. This, he inherited from his illustrious parents. Both the late Mr. S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike and Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike made a permanent impact on the foreign policy of this country. Anura derived inspiration from this great tradition of his illustrious parents. He always looked at foreign policy issues from a scholarly point of view. Anura Bandaranaike, when he entered politics was in a unique position because all the factors were to his great advantage. He came from the legendary Bandaranaike family which dominated the political landscape of Sri Lanka for more than 50 years. His illustrious father, the late Mr. S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike, was the architect of the political change of 1956 and his charismatic leadership was a source of great inspiration. His mother, Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike was the worlds first woman Prime Minister. Who in this country can claim such advantages, such massive political advantages? His sister was elected twice as the President of this country. Anura Bandaraniake began with tremendous political advantages. The dynastic politics became important during that period and he, though intelligent and educated, could not make use of these advantages to reach the top of the political ladder. That was very unfortunate. That was the most unfortunate fact. Unlike his illustrious parents who bestrode the Sri Lankan political landscape in the form of a colossus, he could not understand the political currents of the period. Though he derived inspirations from the ideological positions of his parents, he remained slightly rightist. I do not say that it is a "right of centre". He remained slightly rightist. He could be described as a politician with a rightist stance. He failed to understand the role of the established traditional left of this country. That was a major mistake he committed. He never understood the historical role of the traditional left of this country and he crossed swords with them at the very initial stage of his political career. This, in my view, debilitated his political career at the very initial stage itself. It was this stance of his which prevented him from emerging as a national political leader. The differences within his family and the political orientations of certain members of his family, especially ideological positions, alienated him and he eventually joined the UNP. His entry into the United National Party showed that he never understood the political philosophy of his illustrious parents who founded the great Sri Lanka Freedom Party. They were great political strategists and pragmatists. He could not make use of the charisma of the Bandaranaikes' especially the charisma of the late

Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike. He could not understand the dynamic political role of the late Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike who, in the Sri Lankan context, was a political phenomenon. Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike was a political phenomenon. She was a great woman politician of the century. Anura, crossed swords with Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike and joined the UNP. I can remember, I was in the Central Committee when he left, and I can remember the debates which took place inside the Central Committee of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party. Even in 1982 he buckled the late Hon. Hector Kobbekaduwas campaign by calling him a contractor. He, at one stage thought that the SLFP was their private property, and this kind of attitude distanced himself from the rank and file of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party. He never understood the populist historical foundations of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party. He could not understand the nature of the political base of the SLFP. He could not come to terms with the historical traditions of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party. Though he became a Deputy President of the Party, he could not reach the top because he was not acceptable to the rank and file of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party. A politician, Mr. Deputy Chairman of Committees, has to be consistent; a politician must show an ideological commitment in the given context of politics of a particular country and the failure to display such characteristics would not help a person to emerge as a national leader. In the initial phase itself, there were forces which operated to prevent the emergence of young Anura Bandaranaike as a key person in the Party. In my view, the political ambitions within the Bandaranaike family interfered with his rise to high office. I do not want to go into these details. The very forces which destroyed Anura on ideological grounds in the initial phase tried to rehabilitate him in the early 2000. It was too late. By that time, he had been politically destroyed by those very forces, which at one stage, formed a political party to challenge the Sri Lanka Freedom Party. Certain people formed a political party saying that the Sri Lanka Freedom Party is reactionary and not progressive enough and they wanted to challenge the Sri Lanka Freedom Party. One platform of this political party was to prevent the emergence of Anura Bandaranaike via the Sri Lanka Freedom Party. The politics of the subsequent period demonstrated the extent to which Anura Bandaranaike has been misled and misguided and he, in the end, failed to achieve what he had aspired from the time of the assassination of his illustrious father. With Anura Bandaranaikes untimely death, the dynasticism in the Sri Lankan politics came to an end. The popular base of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party had been activated under a new leadership and the nature of the political change is such that dynasticism, which

dominated the politics of the Sri Lanka Freedom Party for more than 50 years, had been dumped inside the dustbin of history. Anura Bandaranaike was an astute politician. Nobody denies that. He was an astute, capable politician who missed the bus due to his own follies. It is very unfortunate that he missed the bus due to his own follies and also due to the ambitious intrigues and rivalries of his own family members. Anura, with his all astuteness could not exploit the fund of goodwill, the fund of popular goodwill, which the Bandaranaikes built in this country since the 1930s. With all his ability, he failed to achieve anything substantial in the arena of Sri Lankan politics. As my good Friend, the Hon. Dinesh Gunawardena said, it is up to the historians of the party or the historians of this country to examine and analyse the political and social reasons, which culminated in the total failure of Anura Bandaranaike as a politician of the legendry Bandaranaike dynasty. Thank you. [. . 12.47] ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Mervyn Silva - Minister of Labour) , - - . . . 1970 , . , " . . . . . . , .. , ." . . . . - - , ", , " . . . - - "" , . . , . . . . . . .

. , . , . - - . - - . , . , . . . , Some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon them . . .
- , ) (The Hon. Mahinda Yapa Abeywardene - Minister of Cultural Affairs and National Heritage) , . , , , . . , , . . .

[. . 2.33] ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Lasantha Alagiyawanna - Minister of Road Passenger Transport) , , . , , . , . , . , , . .... , , , . . . , , , . . . . , . , , . . . , . , . . ; . . . , , .

Bismillahir Rahmanir Raheem. Mr. Presiding Member, I am much privileged to pay tribute to a great son of Sri Lanka, the late Hon. Anura Bandaranaike who parted us a year ago. It was only Anura who had the pride to be born as the son of two national leaders - the late Hon. S.W.R.D. Bandaranaike and the late Hon. (Mrs.) Sirimavo Bandaranaike - who reigned the country as Prime

Ministers. Anuras mother, the late Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike became the First Woman Prime Minister in the World in the year 1960. She served as the Prime Minister from 1960 to 1964, then from 1970 to 1977 and later in 1994. She was instrumental in organizing the Non-Aligned Summit Conference in Sri Lanka in 1976, in which leaders of more than 60 countries in the world participated. It was after all these achievements that Mrs. Sirimavo Bandaranaike was disenfranchised by the late President J.R. Jayewardene. Anura Bandaranaike played an active role in the General Elections of 1965, 1970 and 1977. He became a Parliamentarian in 1977 by becoming the second Member of Parliament for the Nuwara Eliya District. Anura had been the chief organizer of the SLFP Youth League since 1973. He became the Leader of the Opposition in Parliament and held this post for a long spell. While being the Speaker of Parliament, he took bold steps to address some problematic issues. He staged his protest against the 1978 regime of the late President J.R. Jayewardene by going on a Barefoot Pilgrimage to Kataragama, joining hands with the present President, His Excellency Mahinda Rajapaksa. Anura also held several honorary posts like the Adviser to the Minister of Planning and Economic Affairs from 1974 to 1977 and a Member of the Education Ministry (Advisory) Bureau. Anura had his education at Royal College, Colombo and then qualified himself as a Bachelor of Arts from the University of London. When he was in Europe, he organized the SLFP Youth League there. He was a good orator, both in the Sinhala and English languages. He was a man of independent thinking and the most liberal of politicians. He was open to discussion, negotiation and even to conviction. Anura was able to reconcile extremes of opinion, not merely to satisfy the needs of practical politics but also to accept them from an ideological standpoint. This was a unique feature. A party as well as an individual needs such thinking, and that is the void that Anura has created by his death. Anura Bandaranaike had a good rapport with the minor communities in Sri Lanka. He was well-respected by all communities for his gentle and harmless politics. Anura had a very close association with my father, the late Hon. A.L. Abdul Majeed who was the Deputy Minister of Information and Broadcasting. I recollect that when Anura visited Mutur in 1983, he received a warm welcome. He had the opportunity of talking to all communities and was very compassionate in listening to the difficulties faced by them in their practical living. In fact, Anura was a very affable politician respected and loved by all walks of life, all party politicians and as a whole by the Sri Lankan people. His death is a big loss to the people of Sri Lanka. Thank you very much.

( ) (The Presiding Member) I wish to associate myself with the sentiments expressed by both sides of the House on the death of the Hon. Anura Bandaranaike, ex-Speaker of Parliament and
ex-Minister. I direct the Acting Secretary-General of Parliament to make a Minute of today's Proceedings and send a copy thereof to the members of the bereaved family. Thank you. ( )
